author: LAPhill
content:
Shout out to @Tim O’Sullivan for not only finally solving my hum issues, but dialing in the workflow in my room to a whole other level. He wired up all my pedals, synths, and preamps to a couple of patch bays so I can throw signal all around the room in any order (complete with right-angle cables so I can use them with the desk doors closed). He also built MIDI lines to send clock from my DAW to the pedals and we upgraded the room to Mio MIDI-over-Ethernet units. Several other creature comforts that allow me to think less, like routing a headphone connection underneath the right side of my desk instead of the left where my interface is, adding a second one by the piano, and ready-to-go cables for guitars, synths and microphones already plugged in where they need to be.

I'm going to run out of reasons not to call this studio "done" soon.

author: Rollmottle
content: Nice vibey spot! If you want to go down the rabbit hole all the way, the speakers should be all the way up against the back wall. Remove the treatment from the center there and put them right up against the wall. Where they are now, they look really wide and you'll still be feeling the effects of the gap between their position and back wall. You might be getting even more boundary effect from them being so close to the side walls as well. It might be counterintuitive to remove the treatment from the middle, but it really will probably help more than not. Yes, then you will have to deal with the big screen right in the sweet spot, but one step at a time lol.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Part of what I did today too was put the center of my Sterling desk precisely on the centerline of the room and precisely the same distance from the front wall so I could use it as a reference. Once I got that locked in, I used my Bosch double laser thingy mounted to a tripod to reference to the room centerline and then also cast a horizontal line across the room, across the front of the speaker platform. Since both stands and platforms were now actually level, it was easy to see that the platform of the right speaker stand was slightly out vs. the left. So I had to very gingerly and carefully fuck with the platform to get it lined up. Then fine tuning of leveling with the feet. Then, using the double laser thing at the centerline, I verified the height at the speaker platforms by using that translucent target thing to make sure the cross-line it was casting, hit the target as expected (it did) . I did have to do a bunch of nudging of the right speaker stand to match its position from the right and rear wall to match the left speaker's position, which was a pain int he ass.

Definitely an ordeal and was made much easier with the tools I have. Pretty satisfying seeing identical measurements from the same reference points on either speaker stand.

author: popaganda.
content: Can I interject and steer the convo in a direction that might help some of the lurkers? I tried to throw ns10s into the mix a few years ago and they really confused me. But I can't deny that my heros made great shit on them. There seem to be 2 common denominators I've seen for ns10 people. Either you came up in big studios and they were always there as a reliable reference and you learned them over time. In this context part of the sound of the ns10 is actually the desk reflection. Or you learned from a mentor who worked on them and picked up all the voodoo tricks that helped make them translate. Anybody who had a real mentor likely understands ns10s because they were ubiquitous to genX and before. I'm trying to understand if there's any use to a 25 year old now who's never been in a big studio or had a mentor and wants to do good work. I was the first to discourage someone from getting them yesterday in monitoring. Was my take wrong?

author: Maxim
content:
So I'm currently doing all of this (removed screen as well). I'm not sold just yet. 

Few issues: the listening position is still best in my old spot (about 34% into the room). So I have to pump more sound than before to get the same "feeling". Phantom center is also not as clear.

Also, the idea of getting a triangle gets thrown out the window. I'm further away than they are apart. Bass of course is bigger (even with a -6db roll-off) but I'm not sure if it's actually useful. And it seems like the walls are now vibrating more (already had a neighbor asking what I'm up to).

And for some reason records that sounded great to me before now sound unlistenable and harsh in the upper mids. Not sure if this is true just yet though (see Walking on a Dream by Empire of the Sun). If this is what other people are also hearing maybe it's the detail I've been missing in the mids. Some songs are really painful.

On the plus side, the room is a bit "deader" and even now because I moved the treatment to the back (where previously there wasn't much). Also, reverb tails are very clear now. Before I couldn't really hear FX until I overdid them and dialed back. I'll try doing a mix like this and see if I intuitively make better decisions.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I would be very curious to hear the unfuck guys' chat tube traps! I keep seeing Jon’s in pics and curious to hear his thoughts as well.

They have been great for me. I scored my whole set in 2 batches (16 tubes, 3 speaker stands) for roughly $4500 total - which is still pricey but a great “deal.” Also, they make my Apartment’s basement bedroom usable. 

They lock you into a very specific aesthetic and ergonomic setup, which I have found interesting to navigate (placing a desk, can’t adjust speaker height, etc.).

They also sound great for tracking! I have used them while tracking drums, harp, vocals, and other things with excellent results.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Yes, for sure! As a renter, work-from-home option, they are a dream. I think you could get better ergonomics and potentially better sound from other studio design options, but the flexibility is great. They are definitely not a magic bullet to get a “flat room” either and placement / quantity can affect things greatly. 

Andrew Maury was the one who inspired my initial purchase! He does fantastic work on them and was definitely a great resource as I was looking into them. He shared this video with Greg from Kush audio which was very convincing at the time  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=P7pOA4eeuS0&t=72m13s

I also have friends who have had good success building diy tube traps — which can be pretty affordable.

Totally off-center mix position, but I think this would optimize my new room, instead of dividing the recording spaces on either side of the desk. author: peterlabberton
content:
My future setup. Will of course need to adapt as I get in the room and listen, but I'm excited *and* need to minimize downtime between studios, so I'm mapping stuff out as best I can so I can hit the ground running.

I'm thinking I'll build some fiberglass/rockwool panels on stands (the four panels freestanding by the mix position) and mimic some of the idea behind the attack wall: kill reflections closer to the listening position rather than at the walls. This way I can keep the fireplace and windows from being covered up, and have some gobos to move around when needed for tracking. The small desk to the left of the mix position will be a rack for gear, the large rectangular thingy in the upper right will be an upright piano. I'll pack in some DIY tube traps around the monitors, and hang two 4'x2' panels I already own over the mix position. I'll also put two slightly smaller panels over the drums, and two more on the wall behind the drums. The french doors and the sliding doors to the closet behind the couch will have heavy curtains.

author: peterlabberton
content:
This is the kind of nerdy tweaky shit I think this discord will appreciate: got my lil S1 control surface a few days ago, and used setting it up as an excuse to also play around with the arrangement of my tiny desk, and add some EQ to my monitors.

Tried the S1 behind my keyboard (too deep and potential for more reflections), and off to my left (weird neck craning all day), and landed here for now. Then busted out a mirror and angled my desk to avoid any reflections from the monitors at the listening position. Shot the room again and popped this EQ on the output in UAD Console (it’s finally good for something!!), and am very pleased with the new arrangement. 🎉

Ruairi might have a fit with this EQ curve, but I’m ABing it in and out and it’s definitely helpful, until I get my act together and build some membranes!

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I have a Hilo goes AES to speakers and as my send/capture for the Massive Passive...you can't see it here but there is a rack under the screen where it sits. I have a side car off the side (the walls look pretty tight but they are actually the unf*ck mass loaded vinyl L things, so the room opens up more behind them). The sidecar is back from those...its got a apogee symphony taking the ins for my synths (also not really pictured -- just hangarounds from my production days for the fun of it sometimes), Hazelrigg VLC in there too.

There is sorta a whole room behind the listening position...its 30 feet long with a floating wall for absorption about 15 feet in so the studio is like 13x15 but acoustically its larger if that makes sense.

I do use streamdeck...but mainly to switch quickly between the hot ref in Wavelab and my master. I've gotten deep into Applescript which essentially handles all of the other Wavelab processes...it's almost finished but my streamdeck will essentially just launch those applications to do what I need. So I'd say it's very useful, but the coding I've been able to do will render it sorta meaningless for me (though convienent, I use it for other things like navigating websites when doing client outreach, etc which is very handy and makes my workflow like an order of magnitude quicker).

Chair is hag capisco. I love it. Had a serious back injury when I was younger so I'm pretty dialed into having things be ergonomic and I find it's great. Actually kinda rather uncomfortable...in a good way. You can't really slouch. Took some getting used to but it's interesting

author: masteredbyjack
content:
For those interested in the tiny desk/midi thing (and want to do it premium) — had a 37 key fatar keyboard midi controller built into my desk, purely for hobby reasons, I never use it mastering but I like to touch keys every so often to stay connected with the creative side of the process. Slides in on accuride slides and is beastly sturdy, does not move at all when played.

And since it can be attached to the slides from the side of the keyboard, you can get it right up to the bottom of the desk, you’d never know it was there (and since all day every day is mastering for me that’s very important in my case!)

author: Zack Hames
content:
Has anyone gone down the rabbit hole of ways to manipulate your space to be more productive/focused? Things like lighting, wall colors, types of furniture or layout, temperature, acoustics based things, computer screen brightness, etc etc. 

Things that promote focus, creativity, allows for less stress/better focus. Could be literally anything

author: Zach Hughes
content: I've been going down this rabbit hole recently. I purchased and have started using a phone lock box. Kinda hardcore. Not gonna be necessary for everyone. There's also a program called freedom (probably similar to focus app mentioned) I just got and will be experimenting with. Have a program called flux that changes the color hue of my screen as the day progresses to make it easier on the eyes. I think blue light earlier in the day and yellow ish light later in the day? Some science I don't really understand behind that. There's a huberman lab out there somewhere about it. I backlit my screen display with blue leds as well. Honestly one of the best things when I actually stick to it is trying to never sit for longer than an hour. Even just a 5 minute stand up walk around helps me immensely. Related I drink a ton of water and forces me to get up to go to the bathroom more often.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not sure what I’m gonna do long term. I like them on the meter bridge, at least in the old studio, because they’re closer to my ears that way. In the old studio I experimented having them on stands behind the desk but it put the speakers weirdly far and that room didn’t carry the sound well. 

I may do cinder block stands behind the console if I like how they sound in that position then I can put my ns10’s on the meter bridge stands

author: cian riordan
content: When you're done hemhoragging money on your install, I'd suggest sound anchors to hold the speakers. They will give you more flexibility over cinder blocks, allow you to lever the speakers over the console if you like, and will decouple them from the desk so you're not feeling the low end through your fingers/hands.
